Authors: Prem M, Saavedra S, Vargas JF
Title: End-of-conflict deforestation: Evidence from Colombia's peace agreement
Methodology: Difference-in-differences analysis of deforestation rates pre/post ceasefire using Hansen GFC data
Key_Findings: FARC-controlled areas experienced differential increase in deforestation after ceasefire; effect attenuated by state presence and judicial capacity; exacerbated by land-intensive economic activities
Gap_Identified: No remote sensing-based LULC classification; focused on deforestation only not full LULCC matrix

Authors: Clerici N, Armenteras D, et al.
Title: Deforestation in Colombian protected areas increased during post-conflict periods
Methodology: Analysis of 39 protected areas comparing deforestation 3 years before and after 2016 peace agreement using Hansen GFC
Key_Findings: 31/39 protected areas (79%) experienced increased deforestation; 177% increase in deforestation rate; 330 km2 additional forest loss
Gap_Identified: No analysis of non-forest LULC transitions; no ecosystem services quantification

Authors: Castro-Nunez A, Mertz O, et al.
Title: What Peace Means for Deforestation: An Analysis of Local Deforestation Dynamics in Times of Conflict and Peace in Colombia
Methodology: Local-level analysis of deforestation dynamics linking armed conflict intensity to forest loss using panel data
Key_Findings: Deforestation linked to large-scale cattle ranching and land speculation rather than small-scale agriculture; 40% increase in forest-to-agriculture conversion post-conflict
Gap_Identified: Limited spatial resolution; no GEE-based analysis; Magdalena Medio not specifically analyzed

Authors: Clerici N, Salazar C, et al.
Title: Spatial-temporal dynamics of deforestation and its drivers indicate need for locally-adapted environmental governance in Colombia
Methodology: Spatial analysis of deforestation drivers at municipal level combining socioeconomic and environmental variables
Key_Findings: Deforestation drivers are spatially heterogeneous; locally-adapted governance needed; cattle ranching and coca cultivation as main drivers
Gap_Identified: No LULC classification; focused on deforestation drivers not full transition analysis

Title: Identifying hotspots of deforestation and reforestation in Colombia (2001-2010)
Methodology: Moran I global clustering + Getis-Ord Gi* hotspot analysis of woody cover change from MODIS VCF
Key_Findings: Identified Magdalena Medio as deforestation hotspot; no protected areas in Magdalena Medio hotspot; reforestation in Caribbean coast and Andean highlands
Gap_Identified: Pre-peace agreement data only; no post-2016 analysis; coarse MODIS resolution

Authors: Etter A, McAlpine C, et al.
Title: Regional patterns of agricultural land use and deforestation in Colombia
Methodology: Analysis of agricultural expansion patterns and deforestation using census data and remote sensing
Key_Findings: Agricultural expansion as primary deforestation driver; regional patterns vary significantly; Magdalena Medio affected by cattle ranching expansion
Gap_Identified: Outdated data; no post-conflict analysis; no GEE methodology

Authors: Phalke AR, Ozdogan M, et al.
Title: Land cover classification using Google Earth Engine and Random Forest Classifier - The Role of Image Composition
Methodology: Random Forest classification on GEE using Landsat 8; tested different temporal composite strategies
Key_Findings: Overall accuracy >84.3%; summer scene composites achieved 89.8% accuracy; temporal aggregation improves classification
Gap_Identified: Not applied to tropical Colombia; no post-conflict context

Authors: Zhang X, Liu L, et al.
Title: Optimal parameters of random forest for land cover classification with suitable data type on Google Earth Engine
Methodology: Systematic evaluation of RF parameters (ntree mtry) data types and compositing methods on GEE
Key_Findings: RF parameters significantly affect accuracy; optimal ntree=500; median composites outperform mean; multi-temporal features improve OA to >90%
Gap_Identified: Methodology transferable but not tested in Colombian tropical humid forest context

Title: Land cover classification at three different levels from optical and radar Sentinel data: case study in Cundinamarca Colombia
Methodology: Fusion of Sentinel-1A SAR and Sentinel-2A optical data with Random Forest for tropical LULC
Key_Findings: Fusion improved accuracy to 68-82% depending on classification level; radar valuable for cloud-prone tropical regions
Gap_Identified: Not in Magdalena Medio; demonstrates Colombia-specific RS challenges

Title: Identification of disturbances in Colombian tropical rainforest using LandTrendr algorithm
Methodology: LandTrendr algorithm applied to Landsat NDVI time series 2000-2017 for forest disturbance detection
Key_Findings: Confirmed reliable change detection across forest disturbance categories; annual deforestation rate 0.46% nationally 0.77% in Caqueta
Gap_Identified: Applied in Amazon not Magdalena Medio; demonstrates feasibility of LandTrendr for Colombian tropical forests

Title: How BFAST trend and seasonal model components affect disturbance detection in tropical dry forest and temperate forest
Methodology: Evaluation of BFAST Monitor algorithm components for forest disturbance detection in different biomes
Key_Findings: Seasonal component critical for tropical forests; trend+season model outperforms trend-only; latency varies by forest type
Gap_Identified: Not applied to humid tropical forest of Magdalena Medio; methodology transferable

Title: Integrating forest cover change and carbon storage dynamics: GEE and InVEST to inform conservation in hilly regions
Methodology: Combined GEE for LULC mapping with InVEST carbon storage model; trajectory analysis of land transitions
Key_Findings: Demonstrated integration of GEE+InVEST workflow; quantified carbon storage changes linked to LULC transitions
Gap_Identified: Not tropical Colombia; methodology directly applicable to Magdalena Medio study

Title: Trade-offs and synergies between ecosystem services in response to land cover change in Colombian Andes
Methodology: Assessment of multiple ES trade-offs using spatial analysis of LULC change impacts
Key_Findings: Not all ES trade-offs are equal; spatial patterns of synergies/trade-offs vary with land cover type and region
Gap_Identified: Andes focus not Magdalena Medio lowlands; limited to Andean ecosystems

Title: Assessing impact of land use changes on carbon storage by linking trajectory analysis and InVEST
Methodology: Combined land use trajectory analysis with InVEST carbon model to assess temporal carbon dynamics
Key_Findings: Trajectory-based approach captures non-linear carbon changes better than simple before-after comparison
Gap_Identified: Methodology applicable; demonstrates trajectory+InVEST integration for carbon assessment

Title: A geographically weighted random forest approach to evaluate forest change drivers in the Northern Ecuadorian Amazon
Methodology: GWR combined with Random Forest for spatially varying deforestation driver analysis
Key_Findings: GW-RF achieved predictions >74% using OOB samples; distance to roads and population density as main drivers
Gap_Identified: Adjacent to Colombia; methodology directly transferable; demonstrates GWR+RF for tropical deforestation

Title: Assessing local variations of deforestation processes in Mexico using GWR
Methodology: GWR to analyze spatially varying deforestation drivers at municipal level
Key_Findings: GWR increased R2 from 0.69 (global OLS) to average 0.72 (local GWR); significant spatial heterogeneity in drivers
Gap_Identified: Demonstrates GWR superiority over global models for deforestation analysis; not applied to Colombia

Title: Predicting LULC changes for sustainable land management using CA-Markov modelling and GIS
Methodology: CA-Markov model for simulating 16-year LULC change scenarios; projected to 2054
Key_Findings: CA-Markov achieved OA 93.6% Kappa 0.92; reliable long-term prediction tool for LULC scenarios
Gap_Identified: Methodology applicable for future scenarios in Magdalena Medio; not tropical forest context

Title: Spatial regression analysis of Colombia's narcodeforestation with factor decomposition
Methodology: LISA local Moran I analysis + spatial regression of deforestation and coca crops at municipal level
Key_Findings: 57 municipalities in High-High cluster; 383 in Low-Low; positive spatial autocorrelation between deforestation and coca; socioeconomic factors significant
Gap_Identified: Direct Colombia context; narcodeforestation relevant to Magdalena Medio; no LULC classification

Title: Fragmentation increased in over half of global forests from 2000 to 2020
Methodology: Novel connectivity-based metrics applied to global forest cover data 2000-2020
Key_Findings: 51-67% of forests globally and 58-80% of tropical forests became more fragmented; shifting agriculture drives 61% of tropical fragmentation
Gap_Identified: Global study; need to apply fragmentation metrics specifically to Magdalena Medio

Title: Impact of deforestation on habitat connectivity thresholds for large carnivores in tropical forests
Methodology: Connectivity modeling for large carnivores under deforestation scenarios in tropical landscapes
Key_Findings: Deforestation-driven fragmentation pushes habitat below connectivity thresholds; non-linear relationship between forest loss and connectivity
Gap_Identified: Provides framework for connectivity analysis applicable to Magdalena Medio biodiversity assessment

Title: Assessing the effect of natural controls and land use change on sediment yield: Magdalena drainage basin Colombia
Methodology: Sediment yield analysis combining hydroclimatic and land use data for Magdalena basin
Key_Findings: Erosion in Magdalena basin increased 33% between 1972-2010; human-induced soil erosion reduces freshwater ecosystem services
Gap_Identified: Direct Magdalena context; demonstrates hydrological impacts of LULC change; outdated needs update with post-conflict data

Title: Recent deforestation causes rapid increase in river sediment load in Colombian Andes
Methodology: Analysis of sediment load trends linked to deforestation in Andean tributaries of Magdalena River
Key_Findings: Rapid increase in sediment load directly correlated with deforestation intensity; implications for water quality and hydropower
Gap_Identified: Magdalena relevant; establishes deforestation-hydrology link; needs post-2016 update

Authors: Oregon State / Fagan ME et al.
Title: Peace accord in Colombia has increased deforestation of biologically-diverse rainforest
Methodology: Analysis of 30 years of land transfers and forest cover change pre/post peace agreement
Key_Findings: 40% increase in forest-to-agriculture conversion post-conflict; land markets by wealthy actors driving deforestation; slow conservation governance implementation
Gap_Identified: High-impact finding; no Magdalena Medio specific analysis; no full LULC matrix

Title: Land Cover Change in Colombia: Surprising Forest Recovery Trends between 2001 and 2010
Methodology: MODIS VCF analysis of forest cover trends at national and ecoregion level 2001-2010
Key_Findings: Magdalena-Uraba Moist Forest showed decrease in mixed woody class; 46% transitioned to woody vegetation 44% to ag/herb; Magdalena Medio showed dynamic transitions
Gap_Identified: Pre-peace data; Magdalena Medio specifically mentioned as dynamic area; needs post-2016 update with finer resolution

Title: PlanetScope Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-1 Data Integration for OBIA Land Cover Classification in GEE
Methodology: Object-based image analysis combining optical+SAR on GEE with machine learning
Key_Findings: Multi-sensor fusion improved OA to 82-91%; OBIA outperformed pixel-based in heterogeneous landscapes
Gap_Identified: Methodology applicable for Magdalena Medio; multi-sensor approach recommended for cloudy tropics
